summary_points: 1. On March 26, 2025, AutoZone, Inc. amended its bylaws to lower the shareholder voting percentage required to call a special meeting from a majority to 25%.
2. The filing is an 8-K Current Report, indicating a significant event occurred on March 26, 2025.
3.  The bylaw amendment, effective immediately, potentially increases the influence of minority shareholders in corporate decision-making.
1. Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. entered into a credit agreement on March 28, 2025, to finance its seventh Oasis-class ship, scheduled for delivery in the second quarter of 2028.

2. The 100% BpiFrance Assurance Export-guaranteed loan will amortize semi-annually and mature twelve years after the ship's delivery, accruing interest at a floating rate of Term SOFR plus 0.85% per annum.
3.  The credit agreement includes customary events of default, including non-payment, covenant breach, default on other debt, large judgments, and a change of control of the company.

1. On March 31, 2025, O’Reilly Automotive, Inc. amended and restated its credit agreement, establishing a five-year, $2.25 billion unsecured revolving credit facility with an option to increase commitments by up to $900 million.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, O’Reilly Automotive, Inc. increased the size of its commercial paper program from $1.8 billion to $2.25 billion.

3. The amended credit agreement includes customary covenants, such as limitations on subsidiary indebtedness, a minimum consolidated fixed charge coverage ratio of 2.50:1.00, and a maximum consolidated leverage ratio of 3.50:1.00; failure to meet these ratios could lead to default.
1. O'Reilly Automotive, Inc. announced the release date for its first-quarter 2025 earnings as Wednesday, April 23, 2025, with a conference call to follow on Thursday, April 24, 2025.
2. As of December 31, 2024, the company operated 6,378 stores across 48 U.S. states, Puerto Rico, Mexico, and Canada.
3. A replay of the April 24, 2025, conference call will be available on the company's website until April 23, 2026.
1. On April 1, 2025, Dell Technologies Inc. completed a public offering of $4 billion aggregate principal amount of senior notes due between 2028 and 2035.
2. The interest rates on the newly issued notes range from 4.75% to 5.5% per year, payable semi-annually.
3.  The notes contain change of control provisions requiring the issuers to repurchase notes at 101% of principal plus accrued interest if a change of control occurs and a subsequent rating decline.
1. Kroger's long-term debt increased significantly year-over-year to $15.8 billion as of February 1, 2025, from $10.2 billion in February 2024.
2. Kroger's net earnings attributable to the company increased by 24% year-over-year to $3.67 per diluted share in fiscal year 2024, while adjusted net earnings decreased by 2%.
3. Kroger anticipates approximately $342 million in benefit payments in 2025 and is evaluating the impact of two new accounting standards.
1. On April 1, 2025, TE Connectivity plc completed the acquisition of Richards Manufacturing Co., a North American leader in utility grid products.
2. The 8-K filing indicates that the acquisition was completed on April 1, 2025, as previously announced on February 11, 2025.
3.  The full details of the Transaction Agreement are to be filed with the Company’s next Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 28, 2025.

1. On March 28, 2025, Exxon Mobil Corp issued $192,803,000 in floating rate notes due 2075, underwritten by Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, UBS Securities LLC, RBC Capital Markets, LLC, Deutsche Bank Securities Inc., and J.P. Morgan Securities LLC.

2.  The notes have optional redemption provisions beginning March 28, 2055, at prices ranging from 105% to 100% of principal depending on the year, and repayment options for noteholders at prices ranging from 98% to 100% of principal, also depending on the year.

3.  The notes' interest rate is a floating rate based on compounded SOFR (Secured Overnight Financing Rate), minus 0.450%, and includes provisions for benchmark transition events and benchmark replacements.
1. Darden Restaurants acquired Chuy's Holdings for $649.1 million in October 2024, financing the purchase with newly issued senior notes.
2.  Nine-month net earnings (ended February 23, 2025) increased by 3.4% year-over-year to $745.8 million, despite $37.6 million in integration expenses from the Chuy's acquisition.
3. Darden projects 50-55 new restaurant openings and $650 million in capital expenditures for fiscal year 2025.

1. On March 30, 2025, Ralph Lauren Corporation amended Halide Alagoz's employment agreement, increasing her minimum annual base salary to $1 million and her target annual stock award value to $2 million, starting in fiscal year 2026.
2. The amendment to Ms. Alagoz's employment agreement will increase her compensation significantly beginning in fiscal year 2026 (anticipated to be in summer 2025).
3. The amendment states that Ms. Alagoz's stock awards are subject to ratification by the Talent, Culture & Total Rewards Committee of the Board of Directors.

1. As of March 27, 2025, Realty Income Corporation had $3.2 billion in liquidity, comprised of cash and cash equivalents, unsettled ATM forward equity, and availability under its revolving credit facility, net of borrowings under the facility and its commercial paper programs.

2. Realty Income intends to increase its revolving credit facility's borrowing capacity to $5.35 billion and extend its maturity, splitting it into facilities for the company and its private capital vehicle.
3. The execution of the new credit facilities is subject to ongoing negotiations and uncertainties, with no guarantee of execution on the described terms or timetable.
1. On April 1st, 2025, Honeywell International Inc. appointed Stephen Williamson to its Board of Directors as an independent director and Audit Committee member.
2. The SEC filing is an 8-K report, indicating a current report concerning significant events, rather than a regularly scheduled filing.

3.  The appointment of Stephen Williamson, who previously held finance positions at Honeywell,  is expected to bring "extensive financial expertise and significant international business experience" to the company.
1. CenterPoint Energy Resources Corp. completed the sale of its Louisiana and Mississippi natural gas distribution businesses on March 31, 2025, for approximately $1.2 billion.
2.  As of December 31, 2024, CenterPoint Energy, Inc. owned approximately $44 billion in assets.
3. CenterPoint Energy plans to use the proceeds from the sale to fund its long-term growth plan,  as stated in a press release issued April 1, 2025.

1. Xcel Energy Inc.'s subsidiary, Northern States Power Company-Wisconsin (NSP-Wisconsin), filed a request for a multi-year electric and natural gas rate increase with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin (PSCW) on March 31, 2025.
2.  The requested electric rate increase totals $151 million over 2026 and 2027, while the natural gas rate increase totals $24 million over the same period.
3. A PSCW decision on NSP-Wisconsin's rate request is expected in the fourth quarter of 2025.
1. As of March 31, 2025, News Corporation repurchased approximately US$655,222,571.20 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2.  On March 31, 2025, 21,394,600 Class A shares and 10,557,834 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$434,602,238.00 and US$220,032,259.74 in consideration, respectively.
3. News Corporation's stock repurchase program, announced previously, intends to continue repurchasing Class A and B common stock subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. Ross Stores' fiscal 2024 (ended February 1, 2025) diluted earnings per share increased 14% year-over-year to $6.32.
2.  The company projects to open approximately 90 new stores in 2025,  with planned capital expenditures of $855 million.
3. Ross Stores generated an $82.6 million cash proceeds from the sale of a packaway warehouse facility in December 2024.

1. GE HealthCare Technologies Inc. entered into two new senior unsecured revolving credit facilities totaling $3.5 billion on March 27, 2025, replacing prior facilities with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. as the administrative agent.
2. The new credit agreements increased the total credit facility from $3.5 billion to $3.5 billion,  a decrease of  $1.5 billion in committed amount compared to the prior agreements.

3. The new credit agreements mature on March 26, 2026 (364-day facility) and March 27, 2030 (5-year facility), and include customary covenants limiting the company's incurrence of liens and leverage ratio.

1. Freeport-McMoRan Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 copper and gold production met expectations, although Indonesian gold sales were impacted by delayed shipments, with no expected material change to annual sales guidance as of March 31, 2025.

2.  The company's average realized copper price for the first quarter of 2025 is projected to be approximately $4.40 per pound, exceeding the London Metal Exchange average quarterly settlement price of $4.24 per pound.

3. Consolidated unit net cash costs for the first quarter of 2025 are estimated to be 5% higher than the January 2025 guidance, primarily due to the timing of gold shipments affecting by-product credits.
